history.content:
I think that you should not really focus on stuff as "combinations of majors" because they really limit you in your learning process, especially in Berkeley where sadly the list of requirements for double majors tend to be quite disproportionate. Math and CS and CS and Data Science have a huge overlap for course requirements, especially in the lower div so in this particular case it will certainly be more manageable, but not something I would strongly recommend, because it will still limit you bc of L&S policies (exhibit A: the only two overlapping upper divs between majors policy).

I think you'd be better off simply taking the classes that seem interesting to you across different departments. If AI and ML are your thing my suggestion would be for you to first take the respective classes in the CS department (188 and 189) and then go into the grad student courses after the necessary preparation that those courses require (I think the next one in the sequences is 289B). Some other courses that you could take for preparation for 189 include EECS 126 which is being propped up a lot within the department atm and 127 which covers optimization. If you were to ask me what was the next logical step to take, I would recommend you to look over the topics covered in 189 and 126/127 and see if there are individual classes in other departments that offer them. I have heard that Stochastic processes (somewhat touched in 126 if I am not wrong) are more strongly developed in the stats department under Stat 150 and most of my friends with a vast ML knowledge in some other schools have strongly recommended taking a dedicated stochastic processes class. I think Sahai talked about this in some thread before so you might want to look a little bit around in Piazza as well

----

Majors become meaningless after spending some time in the industry, so I wouldn't fret too much about which specific majors to go with. Experience trumps everything, so pick your classes/major(s) that'd give you the necessary knowledge/projects for obtaining that experience. Saying "I have worked at X on as a AI/ML Enginner" or "I have completed (an impressive enough) project X on AI/ML" is far greater than saying "I have a double major in CS/DS or Math/DS."

history.content: Out of curiosity, for someone who wants to get into AI/machine learning in industry, which combination of majors would be best? Is the newly created data science major as reputable as CS? It certainly seems better suited for someone who wants to go into ML and already has the mathematical background. Thanks in advance!
history.subject: Math and CS or Math and Data Science
